entry.title: Issue Consuming Custom Business Object (CBO) in RAP CDS View – “Not Permitted” Error
entry.content:
<P>Hi,

I have created a Custom Business Object (CBO) in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud using key user extensibility. I want to consume this CBO in a RAP model to generate an application in Eclipse, using the CBO as the primary business object. However, when I try to use the CBO as a data source in a RAP CDS view, it shows as “Not Permitted.” Please suggest an appropriate approach to resolve this issue.

warm regards

Shiva</p>

entry.title: Re: Two APIs to Retrieve Availability Information
entry.content:
@Bunny 
Sorry, I just saw your question. I guess, this is a misunderstanding. I was not talking about the support of the different stock-types but about temporary reservations. If you e. g. create a sales order the quantities are reserved with a temporary reservation as long as the sales order has not been saved or cancelled. If you use the Info API there are no temporary reservations written as this is a pure check of the availability and two requests will provide the same result.

entry.title: Re: Do the buttons inside SapGuiTextArea on "Create Stand...
entry.content:
These buttons belong to the Textedit Control itself and are completely handled by the control.

If you referred to SAP GUI Scripting events, then the answer is that using these buttons does not cause direct events, but only indirect changes to the content of the Textedit Control (for example when the text is changed by triggering a paste or cut function).

entry.title: How Is Agentic AI in SAP Transforming Core Business Processes Today?
entry.content:
From Deterministic Automation to Agentic Process Execution

Traditional SAP automation operates via predetermined workflows that trigger events under specified circumstances only. Any change from this path necessitated manual actions. The introduction of an intelligent agent into the SAP environment allows for a very different method of operating, in which the agent has the ability to "think", analyze, and resolve problems autonomously.

SAP uses reasoning models and live business context to create AI Agents for SAP. An example of this is an AI agent that monitors the fulfillment of orders. Instead of just flagging an order as delinquent if it is delayed, the AI agent draws on its knowledge of upstream supply constraints and determines whether to re-route inventory or to negotiate new delivery windows with its supplier based on the contractual penalty associated with violating their contract. The logic for making these decisions is not hard-coded; it is inferred from the context surrounding the order.

Additionally, SAP AI supports a feedback-driven execution process whereby each decision made by the AI agent provides a learning opportunity for the next execution cycle. For example, if an agent executes a corrective action that incurs additional costs but does not improve service level performance, it will adjust future decision-making accordingly. This results in a cyclic execution loop as opposed to single-event automation.

Some of the key execution traits include:

  • Goal-oriented reasoning rather than task completion
  • Context-aware evaluation across SAP modules
  • Continuous recalibration based on outcomes

SAP AI Teams designs these agents with explicit governance controls that guide every action. Clearly defined business rules determine what an agent can decide and when escalation is required. Comprehensive audit trails then record the rationale behind each decision, which helps create traceability and accountability. As a result, agent autonomy functions within clearly controlled boundaries rather than operating in isolation.

Agentic Intelligence Across Finance and Controlling Functions

Finance processes within SAP are tightly governed. Yet they remain vulnerable to volume pressure, reconciliation delays, and data inconsistencies. Agentic AI in SAP introduces agents capable of interpreting transactional meaning instead of matching static fields.

For instance, agents that reconcile would review the intent of the posting as well as timing differences and relationships between companies to recommend changes rather than create exception lists. The transition from matching manually to validating decisions allows for faster closes and maintains accuracy.

Moreover, Agentic AI for SAP goes beyond finance by being used in controlling and forecasting. For example, agents that look at a Cost Center’s variance compared to plan provide warnings of potential future variances by correlating delayed purchasing, bottlenecking within operation, and price variability. Instead of standalone variance reports, the Finance team provides a context-specific recommendation with the ability to trace back to source information and assumptions.

Finally, Agentic AI for SAP provides a new definition of compliance monitoring; whereas previously, compliance would check after the posting, agents will check prior to posting, validating whether the transactions align with company policy as well as prior risk history. Predictive controls reduce the need for downstream corrections and/or auditing findings.

Typical finance use cases include:

  • Autonomous account reconciliation proposals
  • Predictive compliance validation
  • Contextual variance interpretation

SAP AI teams emphasize explainability in these scenarios. Each agent’s decision includes rationale, data references, and confidence levels. This maintains trust in regulated environments.

Supply Chain and Operations Under Agentic Control

All supply chains produce large amounts of 'signals', the variation in forecasts, supplier delays, and constraints on logistics result in a chain reaction. These types of 'volatility' are not well-suited to static planning models. An agentic AI is now available as part of SAP. It will allow automated agents to evaluate or negotiate the trade-offs between plans and adjust accordingly.

In demand planning, the AI agent will evaluate forecasts based on both recent and historical consumption and market signals. Instead of sending static alerts, AI agents in the SAP demand planning module will update the planning parameters. This allows for fewer manual overrides that affect the accuracy of the plan.

Operationally, agents monitor execution milestones. When deviations occur, they evaluate options across procurement, production, and distribution. Actions may include expediting materials, reallocating stock, or revising commitments. These decisions consider cost, service impact, and contractual obligations simultaneously.

Additionally, AI for SAP supports cross-functional coordination. Agents share context across modules rather than operating in isolation. This helps reduce fragmented responses and improves execution coherence.

Organizational Readiness and Governance Models

The implementation of agentic AI encompasses an organization’s readiness to use the agentic tool successfully. An organization’s level of readiness is determined by the organization’s ability to ensure data integrity, clarity of its business processes, and the level of governance that has been established.

First, data quality must support reasoning. Agents depend on consistent master data and reliable event streams. Skewed data leads to skewed decisions. Enterprises investing in agentic AI services often begin with semantic data alignment and process instrumentation.

Second, with evolving governance models, organizations set limits and thresholds that allow action authorization without the need for direct action approval for every action. AI agents within those limits and thresholds operate autonomously, with escalation of the process when risk increases or when agents are doubtful in their decision-making. This helps reduce the "approval fatigue" associated with governance models but still allows for oversight.

Security models are evolving as well, whereby agents receive scoped authority and scoped access controls, not only to see the data a user sees but also to take the action the user can take. The decisions that AI agents make in SAP are recorded alongside the decisions made by the human agents, creating one single audit trail for both human and AI agents.

Core governance principles include:

  • Explicit decision boundaries
  • Continuous monitoring of agent behavior
  • Transparent reasoning documentation

SAP AI Teams play a critical role here. They bridge business intent and technical design, ensuring agents act responsibly and predictably.

Final Thought

Agentic AI in SAP signals a structural shift in enterprise execution. SAP systems move beyond recording outcomes toward autonomous action. AI agents in SAP reason across modules, adjust to change, and act within defined constraints. Moreover, AI for SAP reshapes organizational roles and allows SAP teams to operate as agents of change rather than manual intervention.

To develop these agents, SAP teams will need to implement strict guidelines and oversight within their designs. Once agentic systems have been properly developed, they will provide a dependable means of digital operations for organizations to pursue. As more organizations adopt agentic AI into their SAP teams, the companies that invested time and effort into developing mature SAP AI teams and Agentic AI will be the companies establishing the standard for how intelligent enterprise execution will take place in the future.

entry.title: S/4HANA Q2C Sales Flexibility - Default validity Date on Sales Contracts via CPF
entry.content:
Background:

The validity of sales contract identify the certain period that sales representative can main the specific goods are to be sold and under which conditions or special discounts, the sales contracts are valid for this certain time period and the customer fulfill a sales contract by issuing release orders.

Previously, the valid to date of sales contract is not initiated as default, and for quantity contract, the valid from date is not proposed neither, therefore the sales representative has to maintain them correspondingly, otherwise the sales contract is not complete to issue the release orders.

Starting from the S/4HANA Public Cloud release 2602, the default valid from date of sales contract is provided that system uses the creation date as valid-from date.

Additionally, a new flexible solution is provided for configuration expert to define rules that the system uses to determine valid-to dates for sales contracts. These rules enable the flexible calculation of valid-to date based on the calendar and offset rules. This blog illustrates how to maintain configurations to enable flexible determination of valid-to date.

For more details, please see SAP help documentation (link).

CPF

CPF(Configurable Parameter and Formula) is a framework to create flexible formulas to calculate the valid-to date default. CPF allows to specify defaulting rules based on a broad set of parameters in addition to the contract type.

For example, one customer has two sales organizations: 1010 and 1710. Different leading days to calculate the valid to date can be defined for the different sales organizations whilst using the same contract type (CQ)

Sales Document TypeSales OrganizationOffset days
CQ101080
CQ171090

Configuration Steps

Different from On-Premise and Private Cloud system user using Transaction code SPRO to change configurations in backend, user with role “SAP_BR_BPC_EXPERT” needs to use the following SSCUIs to maintain configuration settings in S/4HANA Cloud.

  • Define the Parameter Catalog
  • Define Rules to determine Factory Calendar
  • Define Formulas and maintain the Decision Table
  • Define Custom Routines for Validity Date
  • Assign Custom Routines to Sales Document Types

1. Define the Parameter Catalog

SSCUI 105546, path: Configure Your Solution->Sales->Sales Order Management and Processing->Custom Adaptations for Validity Dates)

The parameters which can be used as conditions of the decision table can be maintained. There are some standard parameters are provided. Custom fields on sales doc header can be added as custom specific parameters.

2. Define Rules to Determine Factory Calendar

SSCUI 103829, path: Configure Your Solution->Sales->Sales Order Management and Processing->Custom Adaptations for Validity Dates->Define Rules to Determine Factory Calendar)

The valid-to date can be proposed by the working days which is defined in factory calendar. For example, the factory calendar is determined by:

  • Firstly, check whether there is a calendar maintained in the sales organization
  • If not, then check whether there is a calendar
  • If still not, then the calendar in the rule is used

3. Define Formulas and Maintain the Decision Table

SSCUI 105547, path: Configure Your Solution->Sales->Sales Order Management and Processing->Custom Adaptations for Validity Dates->Define Formulas for Validity Dates.

A formula consists out of a set of freely configurable parameters which are needed for the execution of the formula and a set of (usage-dependent) tasks, defining what is supposed to be done. The formula-specific implementation of a task, the CPF Routine, is then the logic to be executed. Below steps are required to define a formula:

  1. Define a formula ID 
  2. Assign formula parameters
  3. Define the priority of the parameters
  4. Maintain the decision table

3.1 Define a formula ID

The formula ID is used to assigned to one adaptation scenario for sales contact usage, and the default usage task is SET_VALID_TO_DATE.

3.2 Assign Formula Parameters

Parameter ‘VALID_TO_DATE’ is pre-maintained as returning result. Other parameter catalog maintained in SSCUI 105546 ‘Define Parameter Catalog for Validity Dates’ can be assigned to the formula.

3.3 Define the Priority of the Formula Parameters

In step ‘Assign Parameter Priority’, the priority can be set to the formula parameters which have been assigned to the formula.

3.4 Maintain the Decision Table

The decision table is generated automatically after the priority of the parameter have been defined. The assigned formula parameters can be maintained as conditions. Below fields can be maintained to specify how to calculate the valid-to date:

  • Absolute Offset (in days) 
  • A rule to determine the factory calendar
  • Additional rule to calculate the valid-to date

Additional Relative Offset

Based on given valid-from date, absolute offset, and calendar rule, the system gets an initial valid-to date. Here you can choose how the system processes the initial date to determine the final date. For example, you can choose the first working day in the initially proposed week as the final valid-to date.

4. Define Custom Routines for Validity Date

SSCUI 105548, path: Configure Your Solution -> Sales -> Sales Order Management and Processing -> Custom Adaptations for Validity Dates -> Custom Routines for Validity Dates of Sales Documents.

A customer routine is entrance to enable the Formula of CPF framework, you can define new routine numbers and then assign enhancement ID to the defined routine. You can choose the default Process Enhancement Option task and select the Implementation Type B – Configurable Parameters and Form.

  • Specify the ID and description of the routine
  • Select the process enhancement option task as ‘SD_SLS_FLEX_VALID_TO_DATE’
  • Specify which formula you would like to use in this routine

5. Assign Custom Routines to Sales Document Types

SSCUI 103823, path: Configure Your Solution -> Sales -> Sales Order Management and Processing -> Sales Documents -> Assign Custom Routines to Sales Document Types.

Once the customer routine is defined, it can be assigned to one sales contract type, to enable CPF rules in sales document processing, the custom routine defined in previous step shall be linked to the sales document type.

The customer routine can be assigned to the document type with categories. The section ‘Validity Date’ is only available for sales document types with category Sales Contract. For others the field will be read-only.

Sales Contract Testing

Here we are referring decision table entries with below data:

Sales Document TypeSales OrganizationDistribution ChannelDivisionAbsolute OffsetFactory Calendar RuleAdditional Relative Offset
CQ1010100080ZKET 
CQ1710100090 B

Assuming: the sales contract valid from date is 11/25/2025.

When creating sales contract with type CQ and sales area 1710/10/00, system will hint the second line of decision table. The valid to date determines to 02/28/2026 which considers the initial valid from date: 11/25/2025, absolute offset: 90 and additional relative offset: B - last day of month.

1. Log into S/4HANA Cloud system using user with role “SAP_BR_INTERNAL_SALES_REP”.

2. Create a sales contract in Manage Sales Contracts – Version 2

When creating sales contract, the valid-to fields will be set automatically. When changing the valid-from date during the creation, the valid-to date will also be recalculated automatically. For example, when entering the create view, the valid-to date is immediately set as 90 days after the valid-from date. If changing the valid-from date, the valid-to date is immediately updated to 90 days after the valid-from date.

Sales Organization 1710:

Additional Notes

  • This functionality is also available for sales quotation and sales inquiry.
  • This functionality is also available when creating sales quotation via OData API. An exception is creating sales quotation via OData API with reference. In this case, the automatic determination of valid-to date will not be triggered.
  • Automatically setting the valid-to data is only available when creating sales contracts. It will not be triggered when editing an existing sales contract.

entry.title: Re: S/4HANA 2022 FPS1 Fully-Activated Appliance standard installation
entry.content:
Dear all,

be aware that STEP 4: REGISTER DATABASE will fail if the UIDs and GIDs for the SAP HANA users and groups as defined in the file /hana/shared/HDB/global/hdb/install/support/cfg are occupied. Refer to SAP Note 3686516 "Error Occurred While Registering S/4HANA 2023/2025 Fully-Activated Appliance (FAA)" for further details.

Best regards
Axel Utz

entry.title: Re: Calculate yearly absences pro-ratio for Compensation Planning
entry.content:
Hi @StephanieBM01 , thank you for sharing this wonderful blog.


I have the exact requirement in my project and have been trying out this solution. I haven’t focused much on the Business Rules and Integration Center jobs yet — for now, I just entered some test values to see how they are pulled into the compensation worksheet.


When the data type of the field “Pro‑Ratio 2024 (LOA)” is set to Decimal, the value is not pulled into the worksheet. However, when I changed the data type to String, the proration value appears correctly in the worksheet as maintained in MDF.


From the blog on FTE and Proration, the recommendation is that the field should be String only when using a proration percentage.


My understanding is that for Business Rules to work, the data type should be Decimal, and for integration with the compensation worksheet it should be String.


I wanted to get your thoughts on this.


Thanks,
Noor

entry.title: Re: What's the table(s) that give "equipment usage period...
entry.content:
Hello @LuisaV ,

here you go:

The information on equipment usage periods by functional locations is primarily stored in the EQUZ table, which must be linked to the ILOA table to retrieve the specific functional location details.

EQUZ (Equipment Usage Period): This table contains time-segmented data for equipment. It records when equipment was installed or dismantled, including "Valid-From" (DATAB) and "Valid-To" (DATBI) dates.
ILOA (PM Object Location and Account Assignment): This table stores the link to the actual functional location (TPLNR).
To find the historical usage periods for equipment at specific functional locations, join these tables using the ILOAN (Location and account assignment). Search by the Equipment Number (EQUNR). Use the ILOAN value from EQUZ to look up the corresponding record in ILOA. The field ILOA-TPLNR will provide the Functional Location ID associated with that specific usage period. You need to align with your ABAP programmer with these two tables.

Regards,

Vaibhav MIshra

entry.title: Archiving B2B Messages from SAP Integration Suite in CMIS Repository
entry.content:
Co - Author: @patricia_torres 

Introduction

In today’s interconnected business landscape, B2B and EDI message exchanges form the backbone of critical business processes, including order management, invoicing, and logistics. These messages often carry legally binding information and must be handled with care. Archiving them within the B2B Capabilities of SAP Integration Suite is not just a best practice it’s a necessity. It ensures compliance with regulatory requirements, provides full traceability for audits, and safeguards data integrity. Beyond compliance, archiving helps maintain system performance by offloading historical data, while also supporting disaster recovery strategies. SAP Integration Suite provides built-in archiving capabilities that allow organizations to store B2B messages and related data in external Content Management Interoperability Services (CMIS) repositories.

This blog introduces the new archiving functionality in B2B Capabilities, explaining how it enhances security, efficiency, and compliance for your integration scenarios.

What is B2B Message Archiving?

B2B message archiving automatically saves your business transaction data from SAP Integration Suite to an external Content Management System (CMIS Repository) that supports the CMIS V1.1 protocol. This includes:

  • EDI messages (like invoices, purchase orders)
  • Message processing logs
  • Transaction details and metadata
  • Business document attachments

The system compresses each B2B transaction into a ZIP file and stores it in the CMIS Repository Reference.

Why Use CMIS Repository?

CMIS (Content Management Interoperability Services) is a standard protocol that allows different content management systems to work together (Reference).

Using CMIS for archiving provides several benefits:

  • Vendor Independence: Works with various content management systems
  • Standardized Access: Uses common APIs across different platforms
  • Scalability: Can handle large volumes of archived data

Setting Up B2B Message Archiving

Step 1: Prepare Your CMIS Repository

First, you need a CMIS-V1.1 compliant repository. Popular options include:

  • SAP Document Management Service on BTP
  • OpenText Core Archive for SAP Solutions
  • Other third-party CMIS systems

For demonstration purposes, I have installed the CMIS workbench referring to the blog.

Step 2: Configure the Destination

To enable B2B message archiving, you must configure a destination in SAP BTP that points to your CMIS compliant repository. This destination acts as the secure connection between SAP Integration Suite and the external storage system.

For General B2B Archiving, you can reuse the existing destination already configured for MPL archiving, as both message logs and payloads share the same repository.

For Dedicated B2B Archiving, set up a separate destination to maintain independent retention policies, authorization concepts, and access controls specifically for interchange payloads.

Correct destination setup is essential for compliance, security, and seamless archiving processes. The following section describes how to create and configure this destination in the SAP BTP cockpit:

  • Destination Name: CloudIntegration_LogArchive
  • URL: Your CMIS repository browser binding URL
  • Authentication: OAuth2ClientCredentials (recommended)
  • Additional Property: RepositoryId = your repository ID

For Dedicated B2B Archiving:

  • Destination Name: CloudIntegration_B2BArchive

Step 3: Enable Archiving

Use the SAP Integration Suite APIs to activate archiving Reference:

  1. Call the activation API: /api/v1/activateB2BArchivingConfiguration

First get the access token using /oauth/token?grant_type=client_credentials and setting client id and client secret as Basic Authentication

 

Use this access token as Authorization Bearer token to activate B2B archiving.

 

  1. Select what you want to archive by going to Agreements under Trading Partner Management capability

Enabling Archiving in TPAs

Activating archiving for Trading Partner Agreements (TPAs) and their associated Business Transaction Activities is straightforward. You simply select the agreement and choose the transaction you want to archive. For each transaction, you can specify whether to archive the source data, the target data, or both. The archiving option is available under the Interchange Settings, making the configuration quick and intuitive.

What Gets Archived?

With CMIS based archiving, B2B message archiving is fully integrated with B2B Monitoring in SAP Integration Suite. All business-relevant data visible in the B2B Monitor, including interchange details, transaction status, partner identifiers, timestamps, and associated metadata, is securely persisted in the CMIS repository. In short, the archive provides a complete snapshot of the transaction context, ensuring full traceability and compliance.

For more details, refer to the official SAP Help documentation (Reference). The following will be archived:

Standard Fields:

  • Transaction status and processing details
  • Partner information
  • Message creation and completion times
  • Document types and directions

Custom Search Fields:

  • Up to 10 custom search attributes
  • Business-specific metadata
  • Custom transaction identifiers

File Format:

  • Each transaction becomes a ZIP file
  • File name format: Business_Document_Data_Content<Interchange ID>.zip
  • Contains all message payloads and metadata

Monitoring and Accessing Archived Data

Once archiving is enabled, archived B2B messages can be easily monitored and verified. The process is fully integrated with B2B Monitoring, where you can check the archiving status of interchanges using standard filters. For deeper inspection, you can connect to the CMIS repository using the Apache Chemistry CMIS Workbench. This free tool allows you to browse folders and download archived files, including both source and target payloads if configured in the Trading Partner Agreement. Together, B2B Monitoring and CMIS access provide transparent and convenient access to archived data.

Using CMIS Workbench

The Apache Chemistry CMIS Workbench is a free tool for viewing archived data:

  1. Download and install CMIS Workbench (Reference)
  2. Connect using your repository URL and authentication
  3. Browse folders to find archived messages – how to query in CMIS (Reference)

I have connected to the CMIS workbench to check the archived messages.

Downloaded the highlighted file.

Both source and target files are archived because I have checked to archive both source and target files in the Agreement.

Archived or Archiving Pending Messages can be checked in B2B Monitoring using the filter as below.

Important Considerations

Before you begin configuring B2B archiving, consider the following operational constraints and technical prerequisites that may impact your setup. Understanding these factors upfront will help you avoid surprises and ensure a smooth implementation. The following sections outline key limitations and system requirements you should review carefully.

Limitations:

  • Archiving job runs once a day and can’t be monitored directly in Integration UI
  • The scheduler runs once a day at a specific time (if needed it is possible to create a ticket to change that time)
  • Currently only completed and canceled messages are archived (failed messages must be manually canceled in B2B monitoring for archiving)
  • No automatic retry for failed archives
  • Archives are sent in single transactions
  • Requires proper authentication setup

System Requirements:

  • CMIS 1.1 compatible repository
  • Proper network connectivity
  • Sufficient storage space in target repository

Best Practices

  1. Test Your Setup: Use CMIS Workbench to verify archives are being created correctly
  2. Monitor Regularly: Check archiving status through the Integration Suite monitoring tools
  3. Plan Storage: Estimate storage needs based on message volume and retention requirements
  4. Security: Use OAuth2 authentication for better security

Conclusion

Archiving B2B messages to CMIS repositories provides a robust and scalable approach to long-term data retention. With SAP Integration Suite, archiving can be enabled easily, even at the level of individual Trading Partner Agreements, while remaining fully integrated with B2B Monitoring. This ensures that all relevant business data and metadata are preserved, offering full traceability and reliable access for compliance, auditing, and analysis.

By leveraging CMIS compliant repositories, organizations benefit from flexibility, scalability, and vendor independence for their enterprise content management needs. Following the recommended configuration steps and best practices helps ensure a secure, reliable, and future-ready archiving setup.

And stay tuned! Our next blog will cover how to retrieve archived messages efficiently so that you can make the most of your archived data.

entry.title: Re: Decimal Places Issue
entry.content:
In general, you should not create this type of parameter outside the usual range; current currencies have between 0 and 3 decimal places.

  • The correct solution is usually to store the required data, such as prices, with a notion of quantity, for example, a currency with 2 decimal places per 1,000 units.

entry.title: IDOCs as Events: How to Simulate and Test Them at Enterprise Scale
entry.content:
The integration landscape within the SAP ecosystem has undergone a significant shift in Q4 2025. For years, the industry narrative suggested that IDOCs were relics of the past, destined to be replaced entirely by SOAP Web Services, later one with OData and REST APIs. However, recent updates have changed the table. Not only are IDOCs officially "safe" for the Clean Core era, but they have also evolved into powerful components of modern Event-Driven Architecture (EDA).

In this post, I will explore why IDOCs are making a comeback and, more importantly, how you can simulate and test these scenarios at an enterprise scale.

The 2025 Turning Point: IDOCs are "Clean Core" Safe

The first major update involves the SAP Clean Core guidance (referencing OSS Note 3578329). As of late 2025, IDOCs are now classified as Clean Core Extensibility Level B as per my blog: IDOCs are Still Safe for SAP S/4HANA - SAP Clean Core Extensibility Level B 

What does this mean for your S/4HANA journey?

  • Existing Investments are Valid: If you have stable, working IDOC integrations, you don’t need to scrap them to be "Clean Core" compliant.
  • Pragmatism over Dogma: While SAP still recommends APIs and Events for greenfield developments, continuing with IDOCs is a pragmatic choice for stable processes, provided the IDOC type isn't deprecated in the S/4HANA Simplification List.

IDOCs Meet the Advanced Event Mesh (AEM)

The second breakthrough is the ability to "event-enable" classic IDOCs using the SAP Event Add-on by ASAPIO as per this blog: IDoc with Integration Suite, Advanced Event Mesh using the Event Add-On

This allows organizations to bridge the gap between legacy reliability and modern real-time agility. By using ASAPIO with SAP Integration Suite, Advanced Event Mesh (AEM), you can:

  • Go No-Code: Send and receive IDOCs through AEM in a near real-time, code-less manner.
  • Payload Transformation: Automatically convert classic IDOC formats to JSON on-the-fly for cloud consumption, and convert them back for inbound processing.
  • Triggering: Link business events in ERP so that a transaction triggers an IDOC extraction and immediate publication to the event mesh.

The Testing Challenge: Scalability and Realism

With IDOCs acting as high-speed events, the question arises: How do we test these scenarios at scale? Standard manual testing isn't enough when you need to validate complex, high-volume event flows.

The Traditional Approach: WE19

The standard tool for simulating IDOCs is transaction WE19 (the IDOC Test Tool). To use it, you find an existing IDOC, use it as a template, modify the data, and trigger it again.

Figure 1 - We19 for outbound processing 

The Limitations:

  • Data Sourcing: Finding the "perfect" IDOC with specific business content is time-consuming (no easy way to search through them) 
  • Lack of Scale: You cannot easily simulate thousands of IDOCs with variable data (different partners, dates, or materials) manually.
  • Isolation: WE19 tests the IDOC in a vacuum, not the end-to-end event flow.

Enterprise-Scale Simulation with Int4 Suite

To truly simulate IDOCs as events for enterprise testing, you need automation. Int4 Suite provides three sophisticated ways to handle this:

A) Simulating Incoming to Trigger Outgoing

In many business processes, an incoming IDOC triggers an outgoing one (e.g., an incoming Sales Order creates an outgoing Order Confirmation). With Int4 APITester, you can simulate the incoming message and use its variable concept to inject dynamic values (like unique PO numbers or current dates).

Figure 3 - variables so each time the IDOC is triggered the content can change dynamically 

 This ensures the resulting "Event" (the outgoing IDOC) is generated by the actual business logic of the system.

Figure 2 - IDOCs as outbound from simulating incoming documents 

B) Triggering via Message Control (NACE/NAST)

Int4 Suite can trigger output directly via SAP Message Control. This simulates how the system works in production (e.g., printing or sending an EDI upon saving a document).

  • How it works: By using the Int4 Suite Knowledge Center guidance, you can trigger the output by calling the necessary functional modules or reports (like RSNAST00) to process specific output types for a range of documents, ensuring the "Event" is fired exactly as it would be by a business user.

Figure 4 - How Int4 Suite can trigger IDOCs with Message Control 

C) AI-Driven Simulation and WE19

The future of testing involves AI Chatbots. Instead of manually navigating WE19, Int4 Suite allows you to use an AI interface to perform selections and data changes. You can instruct the chatbot to "Generate 50 Sales Order IDOCs with varying quantities or different identifiers" and the suite handles the back-end execution in WE19, bridging the gap between conversational AI and legacy SAP transactions.

Figure 5 - Searching for IDOCs and resending them with Int4 Suite Chatbot 

Validating SAP AEM Flows

Once the IDOC is triggered as an event, you must ensure it reaches the SAP Advanced Event Mesh correctly. Int4 Suite allows you to validate these flows by:

  1. Preparation: Configuring the connection between Int4 Suite and SAP AEM to allow the tester to "listen" to specific queues or topics.
  2. Message Selector: Using the Int4 Message Selector, you can pull the actual messages published to AEM and compare them against a "golden" expected payload. This validates that the conversion (e.g., IDOC to JSON) and the routing happened exactly as designed.

Watch it in Action

To see how Int4 Suite handles SAP AEM message selection and validation, check out this technical walkthrough:

Watch: SAP AEM Testing with Int4 Suite

Summary and Next Steps

The combination of Clean Core Level B status and ASAPIO/AEM integration has given IDOCs a second life as modern business events. However, to move these scenarios into production with confidence, your testing strategy must evolve from manual WE19 clicks to automated, variable-driven enterprise simulation.

Want to learn more?

  • Deep Dive: Explore the SAP Learning Course: Avoid SAP S/4HANA Project Delays with Third-Party Systems Service Virtualization to understand how to decouple your testing from external dependencies.
  • Documentation: Visit the Int4 Suite Knowledge Center for detailed configuration guides on SAP AEM and Message Control.

entry.title: SAP ECC vs S/4HANA Integration Capabilities: A Practical Guide for Integration Architects
entry.content:
SAP System Exposure: The Complete Integration Capability Guide for ECC & S/4HANA

1. INTRODUCTION

When I'm asked to integrate an external system with SAP, the first question isn't "which tool should I use?" It's "what can SAP actually expose?"

After few years working across SAP ECC and S/4HANA landscapes with Integration Suite, I've learned that understanding what's available in your SAP system is just as critical as knowing how to integrate it. Yet most integration guides skip this foundation and jump straight to implementation.

This is the reference guide, it maps every integration capability available in SAP ECC and S/4HANA On-Premises systems, explains when to use each protocol, and provides the checklists you need to prepare your systems for Integration Suite connectivity.

What You'll Learn:

  • Complete inventory of integration capabilities in ECC vs. S/4HANA
  • RFC/BAPI, IDoc, OData, SOAP, and file interface fundamentals
  • Protocol comparison matrix with use case recommendations.
  • System preparation checklists for production readiness
  • Integration architecture patterns
  • Decision framework for choosing the right protocol.

Who This Is For:

  • Integration consultants working with SAP landscapes.
  • Solution architects designing SAP integrations.
  • Developers building connections to SAP systems.
  • Functional consultants exploring integration possibilities.
  • Anyone planning Integration Suite implementations.

Let's start with what SAP can actually give us.

 

2. SAP ECC INTEGRATION CAPABILITIES

SAP ECC has been the backbone of enterprise operations for decades. While it lacks some modern REST/OData capabilities, it provides robust, battle-tested integration interfaces that still power thousands of integrations today.

2.1 RFC (Remote Function Call) & BAPIs

RFC is SAP's proprietary protocol for synchronous communication between systems. BAPIs (Business Application Programming Interfaces) are standardized RFCs that provide access to SAP business objects and processes.

Key Characteristics:

  • Synchronous: Call and wait for response
  • Transactional: Can commit or rollback
  • Type-safe: Strongly typed parameters.
  • Widely available: Broad range of reusable standard BAPIs in ECC

Common BAPIs You'll Use:

BAPI Name

Purpose

Use Case

BAPI_PO_CREATE1

Create Purchase Order

External procurement systems posting POs

BAPI_GOODSMVT_CREATE

Post Goods Movement

Warehouse systems updating inventory

BAPI_MATERIAL_GETDETAIL

Get Material Master

E-commerce platforms fetching product data

BAPI_ACC_DOCUMENT_POST

Post Financial Document

External systems creating FI documents

BAPI_SALESORDER_CREATEFROMDAT2

Create Sales Order

CRM systems posting orders to SAP

BAPI_CUSTOMER_GETDETAIL

Get Customer Master

External apps accessing customer data

Technical Details:

  • Access: Transaction SE37 (Function Builder)
  • Discovery: Search pattern "BAPI_*"
  • Testing: SE37 → Test/Execute
  • Authentication: RFC destination in SM59

When to Use RFCs/BAPIs:

Use When:

  • You need real-time, synchronous responses
  • Transaction integrity is critical (commit/rollback)
  • Complex business logic required
  • Creating or updating SAP documents
  • Reading data with complex selection criteria

Avoid When:

  • Processing large data volumes (use IDoc instead)
  • No immediate response needed (use IDoc/async)
  • Simple CRUD on standard entities (use OData in S/4HANA)
  • Performance is more important than transaction integrity.

 Integration Pattern:

EXAMPLE SCENARIO:

Purchase Order Creation from Web Portal

Business Context:
Manufacturing company has external procurement portal where buyers create purchase requests. Once approved, these need to become POs in SAP ECC instantly.

Technical Setup:

  • Source: Custom web portal (Node.js/React)
  • Target: SAP ECC 6.0
  • BAPI: BAPI_PO_CREATE1
  • Frequency: Real-time (on PR approval)
  • Volume: 50-100 POs per day

Process Flow:

2.2 IDoc (Intermediate Document)

IDoc (Intermediate Document) is SAP’s standard asynchronous integration mechanism.
It is designed for high-volume, reliable, loosely coupled data exchange between SAP and external systems.

An IDoc is:

  • Self-contained
  • Status-driven
  • Processed independently of user interaction

This makes IDocs ideal for batch integrations, master data replication, and guaranteed delivery scenarios.

Key Characteristics:

  • Asynchronous: Fire-and-forget or guaranteed delivery
  • Bulk-friendly: Efficient for large volumes
  • Loosely coupled: Systems don't need to be online simultaneously
  • Status-tracked: Built-in monitoring (WE02, WE05)

IDoc Structure:

Common IDoc Types:

IDoc Type

Message Type

Purpose

Direction

ORDERS05

ORDERS

Purchase Orders

Outbound/Inbound

INVOIC02

INVOIC

Invoices

Outbound

MATMAS05

MATMAS

Material Master

Outbound

DESADV01

DESADV

Delivery Notes

Outbound

WMMBXY03

WMMBXY

Goods Movements

Outbound

DEBMAS06

DEBMAS

Customer Master

Outbound

CREMAS03

CREMAS

Vendor Master

Outbound

Technical Details:

  • Access: Transaction WE30 (IDoc Type Development)
  • Partner Setup: WE20 (Partner Profiles)
  • Port Config: WE21 (Port Definition)
  • Testing: WE19 (Test Tool)
  • Monitoring: WE02 (IDoc Display), WE05 (IDoc List)
  • Triggering: Message Control, Change Pointers, IDOC_OUTPUT_* FMs

When to Use IDocs:

Use When:

  • High-volume data transfer (thousands of records)
  • Asynchronous processing acceptable
  • Standard SAP business documents (PO, Invoice, etc.)
  • Batch processing requirements.
  • Need for guaranteed delivery with retry.
  • Master data replication

Avoid When:

  • Real-time response required immediately
  • Complex transformations needed
  • Non-standard data structures
  • Simple CRUD operations (overkill)

Integration Patterns:

Outbound (ECC → External):

Inbound (External → ECC):

EXAMPLE SCENARIO:

Nightly Material Master Sync to Data Warehouse

Company needs to send all material master changes from ECC to external data warehouse every night for reporting and analytics.

Technical Setup:

  • Source: SAP ECC 6.0
  • Target: External Data Warehouse (Snowflake)
  • IDoc Type: MATMAS05
  • Frequency: Nightly batch (2 AM)
  • Volume: 5,000-10,000 materials per night

 End-to-End IDoc Asynchronous Integration Flow

  1. Material master records are created or updated in SAP ECC throughout the day (MM01/MM02).
  2. Change pointers capture only relevant delta changes for the MATMAS message type.
  3. At 2:00 AM, the BD21 batch job executes during off-peak hours.
  4. The system reads accumulated change pointers.
  5. A MATMAS05 IDoc is generated for each changed material.
  6. IDocs are sent via partner profile WAREHOUSE using an HTTP port.
  7. SAP CPI receives the IDoc XML through the IDoc adapter.
  8. CPI parses the hierarchical IDoc structure.
  9. Business data is transformed into a target JSON format.
  10. Records are grouped into batches of 1,000 for optimized processing.
  11. CPI posts each batch to the Snowflake bulk API.
  12. On success, IDocs are updated to status 53 (Posted).
  13. On failure, IDocs move to 51 (Error) and are retried in the next batch cycle.
  14. A consolidated processing report is emailed to the data team at 3:00 AM.

2.3 SOAP Web Services

SAP ECC exposes business functionality as SOAP-based web services using the Enterprise Services Repository (ESR).
These services are WSDL-driven, XML-based, and follow a strict request–response contract over HTTP/HTTPS.

SOAP services are widely used in legacy enterprise landscapes, especially where Java or .NET middleware already exists.

Key Characteristics:

  • Standards-based: WSDL, SOAP 1.1/1.2, WS-* standards
  • Synchronous: Request-response pattern
  • Platform-agnostic: Any SOAP client can consume
  • Structured: XSD-defined schemas

Technical Details:

  • Access: Transaction SOAMANAGER (Service Administration)
  • Development: SPROXY (Proxy Development)
  • Types:
    • Provider Services (ECC exposes to external)
    • Consumer Services (ECC consumes from external)

When to Use SOAP:

Use When:

  • External system requires SOAP/WSDL
  • Enterprise service repository already defined.
  • Need WS-Security features.
  • Cross-platform integration with Java/.NET systems

Avoid When:

  • Modern REST/JSON preferred (not natively supported in ECC)
  • Performance is critical (SOAP overhead)
  • Simple operations (BAPI or IDoc simpler)

Integration Pattern:

EXAMPLE SCENARIO:

Legacy Java Middleware Posting Financial Documents

Existing Java-based middleware system (10 years old) collects invoice data from multiple subsidiaries and needs to post consolidated financial documents to ECC.

Technical Setup:

  • Source: Java middleware (Spring Boot)
  • Target: SAP ECC 6.0
  • Service: FinancialDocumentCreate (Enterprise Service)
  • Frequency: Real-time as invoices arrive
  • Volume: 200-300 documents per day

Process Flow:

  1. Java app collects invoice from subsidiaries.
  2. Validates and enriches data.
  3. Builds SOAP XML per WSDL specification.
  4. Sends SOAP request to CPI endpoint.
  5. CPI routes to ECC SOAMANAGER
  6. Enterprise service validates structure.
  7. Calls backend BAPI for FI posting.
  8. Document posted, accounting entries created.
  9. Returns FI document number in SOAP response.
  10. Java app stores document number for reference.

2.4 File Interfaces

File interfaces are one of the oldest and most reliable integration mechanisms in SAP ECC, designed for scheduled, high-volume, non-real-time data exchange.
Data is exchanged using physical files that are picked up, processed, and archived in batch cycles.

This pattern is still widely used for:

  • Vendor uploads
  • Price lists
  • Mass master data changes
  • One-time or recurring migrations

File Formats:

  • Flat files (fixed width, delimited)
  • CSV/Excel
  • XML
  • Custom formats

Technical Approaches:

  • Output: Report programs, BDC, LSMW
  • Input: Batch Input (BDC), Direct Input, BAPI calls

When to Use Files:

Use When:

  • Batch processing windows.
  • Large data migrations
  • Legacy system integration
  • Offline scenarios

Avoid When:

  • Real-time requirements
  • Frequent small transactions
  • Complex error handling needs.

Example Scenario: Nightly Vendor Price Upload (CSV)

The procurement team receives daily price updates from multiple vendors.
Each vendor uploads a CSV file containing updated material prices, which must be reflected in SAP ECC before business hours.

Technical Setup

  • Source: Vendor SFTP servers
  • Integration Layer: SAP CPI
  • Target: SAP ECC 6.0
  • File Type: CSV
  • Schedule: Nightly (4:00 AM)
  • Volume: ~50 files, 10,000–15,000 records

Process Flow (Clear & Sequential)

  1. Vendors upload CSV price files to the SFTP server between 1:00–3:00 AM
  2. At 4:00 AM, SAP CPI scheduler triggers the batch job
  3. CPI connects to SFTP and downloads all available files
  4. For each file, CPI:
    • Identifies the vendor from the file name
    • Parses the CSV line by line
    • Validates mandatory fields and price values
  5. For each valid record:
    • CPI calls BAPI_MATERIAL_SAVEDATA
    • Updates the vendor price / info record
  6. Processing continues even if individual records fail
  7. CPI writes:
    • Success entries to the success log
    • Failed records to the error log with reason
  8. Processed files are archived to /archive
  9. A summary report is generated
  10. Email notification is sent to the procurement team

WHAT SAP ECC CANNOT DO (WITHOUT WORKAROUNDS)

ECC is powerful for traditional integration, but modern patterns require custom work. Understanding this shapes your architecture strategy.

NO NATIVE REST/ODATA APIS

ECC doesn't provide REST APIs out of the box. You can build them, but not easily:

Workaround Options:

  • NetWeaver Gateway add-on (SEGW)
  • ICF HTTP handlers (IF_HTTP_EXTENSION)
  • Custom ABAP REST wrappers
  • SOAP-to-REST via CPI

LIMITED EVENT-DRIVEN CAPABILITIES

ECC has event-like features, but not modern event streaming:

What You Get:

  • Change pointers (batch-oriented)
  • Workflow events (tightly coupled)
  • IDoc triggers (application-specific)

What You Don't Get:

  • Publish/subscribe architecture
  • Multiple independent subscribers
  • Event replay
  • True decoupling

Impact: Adding a new event consumer requires ECC configuration changes. Not cloud-native.

Why This Works:

  • ECC does what it's designed for: business logic.
  • CPI manages modern protocols, security, governance.
  • No custom code burden in ECC
  • Easy S/4HANA migration path

Strategic Guidance:

  • Use CPI for protocol translation.
  • Keep ECC focused on business processes.
  • Plan your S/4HANA path.

3. SAP S/4HANA ON-PREMISE INTEGRATION CAPABILITIES

S/4HANA builds on everything ECC provides and adds modern integration capabilities that change the game.

3.1 EVERYTHING ECC HAS, ENHANCED

RFCs/BAPIs:

  • All ECC BAPIs available
  • New S/4HANA-specific BAPIs
  • Better performance (HANA database)
  • CDS view consumption via RFCs

IDocs:

  • All ECC IDoc types
  • Improved processing speed
  • Better error handling
  • Enhanced monitoring

SOAP Services:

  • All enterprise services
  • Service adaptation framework
  • Better performance

3.2 ODATA SERVICES (THE GAME CHANGER)

OData is the REST-based protocol that makes SAP data accessible like modern APIs. This is what S/4HANA has that ECC doesn't, and it's transformative.OData introduces true RESTful APIs, designed for:

  • Web applications
  • Mobile apps
  • External developer consumption
  • Real-time queries

Why OData Matters

  • REST over HTTP
  • JSON-first
  • Queryable data access
  • Self-describing APIs

Key Characteristics:

  • RESTful: Standard HTTP methods (GET, POST, PUT, DELETE)
  • JSON/XML: Modern data formats
  • Query-capable: $filter, $select, $expand, $orderby, $top, $skip
  • Self-documenting: $metadata endpoint
  • Stateless: No session management needed

SAP Gateway Architecture:

 

Standard S/4HANA APIs (Examples):

API Service

Business Purpose

Key Entity Sets

API_PURCHASEORDER_PROCESS_SRV

Purchase Order lifecycle management

A_PurchaseOrder, A_PurchaseOrderItem

API_PRODUCT_SRV

Material / Product master data

A_Product, A_ProductDescription

API_SALES_ORDER_SRV

Sales order processing

A_SalesOrder, A_SalesOrderItem

API_BUSINESS_PARTNER

Unified business partner model

A_BusinessPartner, A_BPContactAddress

API_MATERIAL_STOCK_SRV

Inventory and stock levels

A_MaterialStock

Technical Details:

  • Service Registration: /IWFND/MAINT_SERVICE
  • Testing: /IWFND/GW_CLIENT
  • Development: SEGW (Gateway Service Builder)
  • Monitoring: /IWFND/ERROR_LOG

OData Query Capabilities

Basic Read

GET /sap/opu/odata/sap/API_PURCHASEORDER_PROCESS_SRV/A_PurchaseOrder

Filtering

GET .../A_PurchaseOrder

?$filter=DocumentDate ge datetime'2025-01-01'

 and PurchaseOrderType eq 'NB'

Selecting Specific Fields

GET .../A_PurchaseOrder

?$select=PurchaseOrder,Supplier,DocumentDate,TotalAmount

Expanding Navigation Properties

GET .../A_PurchaseOrder('4500000001')

?$expand=to_PurchaseOrderItem

Pagination

GET .../A_PurchaseOrder?$top=100&$skip=0

Response:

"__next": "...&$skiptoken=100"

Metadata Discovery

GET /sap/opu/odata/sap/API_PURCHASEORDER_PROCESS_SRV/$metadata

Returns:

  • Entity sets
  • Properties
  • Associations

When to Use OData

Use When

  • Modern web or mobile applications
  • Real-time queries required
  • REST/JSON integration
  • Flexible query support needed

Avoid When

  • SAP ECC system
  • Complex transactional rollback required.
  • Bulk data transfer

EXAMPLE SCENARIO: Mobile Sales App Querying Products

Business Context:

Sales representatives use mobile app to check product availability, pricing, and specifications while visiting customers. Need instant access to product catalog with real-time stock levels.

Technical Setup:

  • Source: React Native mobile app
  • Target: S/4HANA On-Premise
  • API: API_PRODUCT_SRV, API_MATERIAL_STOCK_SRV
  • Frequency: Real-time as sales rep searches
  • Volume: 500-1,000 queries per day

Process Flow:

  1. Sales rep searches "Bearing" in mobile app
  2. App sends HTTP GET to CPI endpoint
  3. CPI forwards to S/4HANA Gateway
  4. Gateway routes to Data Provider Class
  5. DPC queries HANA database (ultra-fast)
  6. Returns matching products as JSON
  7. For each product, fetch stock level
  8. Combine product + stock data
  9. Response returns to mobile app
  10. Rep sees list: 15 products with prices and stock

3.3 CDS Views as Integration Endpoints

Core Data Services (CDS) views are HANA-optimized semantic data models defined in S/4HANA. They represent business entities and logic at the database level and can be exposed directly for integration.

CDS views can be:

  • Exposed as OData services via SAP Gateway
  • Consumed internally or externally via RFC-enabled function modules

Key Benefits

  • High performance: Logic is pushed down to the HANA database
  • Pre-aggregated data: Reduces processing in the application layer
  • Embedded business logic: Calculations, annotations, and semantics included
  • Rich relationships: Associations allow navigation across related entities

Process Flow

CDS View → Gateway Service → OData → Integration Suite

3.4 SAP Business Events & Real-Time Integration

S/4HANA introduces native event-driven integration capabilities, allowing systems to react immediately to business changes instead of relying on batch jobs or polling.

Key enhancements include:

  • Standardized business event triggers
  • Improved change detection
  • Workflow-driven event publishing
  • Native integration with SAP Event Mesh

Event-Driven Integration Pattern

S/4HANA Business Event → Event Mesh Topic → Multiple Subscribers (CPI iFlows) → External Systems

Typical Use Cases

  • Purchase order approved → Notify procurement portal
  • Stock level falls below threshold → Trigger replenishment
  • Sales order created → Update CRM system
  • Invoice posted → Notify payment or reporting systems

EXAMPLE SCENARIO:

Real-Time Stock Alerts to E-Commerce

E-commerce website needs instant notifications when product stock falls below threshold to display "Low Stock" warnings and trigger replenishment.

Technical Setup:

  • Source: S/4HANA On-Premises
  • Targets: E-commerce website, Replenishment system, Analytics dashboard
  • Event: Material.StockChanged
  • Frequency: Real-time (as goods movements occur)
  • Volume: 2,000-3,000 events per day

Step-by-Step Flow

  1. Goods Issue Posted
    • A goods issue is posted in S/4HANA using transaction MIGO.
  2. Stock Update in HANA
    • The stock quantity is immediately updated in the HANA database.
  3. Business Event Triggered
    • The system triggers the business event Material.StockChanged.
  4. Event Published
    • The event is published to SAP Event Mesh.
    • Topic: inventory/changes
  5. Parallel Event Consumption
    • Multiple systems subscribe to the same event and process it independently.

Subscriber A – E-Commerce System

  • Receives the event through a CPI iFlow
  • Updates the product page inventory
  • Displays a “Low Stock” indicator (e.g., “Only 75 left”)

Subscriber B – Replenishment System

  • Evaluates stock against reorder threshold (100 units)
  • If below threshold:
    • Creates a Purchase Requisition
    • Notifies the purchasing team

Subscriber C – Analytics Dashboard

  • Updates real-time inventory charts
  • Stores event data in the data warehouse for reporting
  1. Independent Processing
    • Each subscriber processes the event independently and in parallel.
  2. Acknowledgement
    • Each system sends an acknowledgement back to Event Mesh.

 

Events are published once and delivered to multiple consumers in parallel, without tight coupling.

3.5 What S/4HANA Adds Over ECC

S/4HANA builds on the proven integration capabilities of ECC and introduces modern, API-driven and event-based features that significantly expand what is possible in real-time and cloud-native landscapes.

Capability

ECC

S/4HANA

Business Impact

OData / REST APIs

Enables modern API-based integrations

JSON Support

❌

✅

Simplifies integration with non-SAP systems

Performance

Medium

Powered by the HANA in-memory database

Now that we understand what each system offers, let's look at how to choose the right protocol and see complete integration scenarios.

4.2  Decision Tree

4.3 Cross-Protocol Integration Scenarios

 

Scenario 1: Manufacturing Company - Complete Landscape

Integration Breakdown

  1. Web Portal → SAP ECC (Purchase Orders)
    • Protocol: REST → RFC/BAPI
    • Purpose: Real-time purchase order creation
    • Volume: ~100 purchase orders per day
  2. SAP ECC → Data Warehouse (Material Master)
    • Protocol: IDoc → JSON
    • Purpose: Nightly master data synchronization
    • Volume: ~10,000 materials per night
  3. Mobile App → SAP S/4HANA (Product Catalog)
    • Protocol: REST → OData
    • Purpose: Real-time product search and availability
    • Volume: ~1,000 queries per day
  4. SAP S/4HANA → E-Commerce Platform (Stock Alerts)
    • Protocol: Business Events via Event Mesh
    • Purpose: Real-time inventory notifications
    • Volume: ~3,000 events per day

5. System Preparation Checklists

Before starting integration development, systems must be technically and operationally ready. The following checklists reflect production-grade prerequisites.

6. INTEGRATION ARCHITECTURE OVERVIEW

Understanding how all pieces fit together:

Component Explanations

Cloud Connector

  • Provides a secure tunnel between SAP BTP and on-premise SAP systems
  • Eliminates the need for VPN connectivity
  • Enables resource-level access control
  • Supports audit logging for compliance and security monitoring

CPI Adapters

  • Enable protocol translation (RFC ↔ REST, IDoc ↔ JSON, SOAP ↔ HTTP)
  • Handle authentication and credential management
  • Support connection pooling for performance optimization
  • Provide built-in retry mechanisms for transient failures

API Management

  • Enforces rate limiting and quotas
  • Supports API key and OAuth-based validation
  • Offers analytics and usage monitoring
  • Includes a developer portal for API discovery and onboarding

Event Mesh

  • Supports publish / subscribe messaging
  • Provides queue-based guaranteed delivery
  • Enables topic-based routing
  • Allows multiple subscribers to process events independently

7. Key Takeaways

Understanding System Capabilities

SAP ECC Strengths

  • Mature and stable RFC/BAPI framework
  • Robust IDoc infrastructure for asynchronous processing
  • Battle-tested reliability in enterprise landscapes
  • Rich Enterprise Services Repository

SAP S/4HANA Advantages

  • Native OData / REST APIs
  • Built-in event-driven integration
  • High performance powered by SAP HANA
  • CDS views for optimized data access
  • Includes everything ECC offers — enhanced and modernized

SAP BTP Integration Suite as the Bridge

  • Centralized protocol translation
  • Secure cloud connectivity
  • End-to-end orchestration layer
  • Enterprise-grade monitoring and governance

Protocol Selection Guidance

  • RFC / BAPI: Synchronous transactions with immediate validation
  • IDoc: Bulk data processing with guaranteed delivery
  • OData: REST APIs for modern applications (S/4HANA only)
  • SOAP: Legacy enterprise web services
  • File Interfaces: Batch processing and data migrations
  • Events: Real-time, decoupled integration (S/4HANA)

Preparation Is Critical

  • System configuration must be completed before development
  • Security and authorizations must be production-ready
  • Network connectivity should be fully tested
  • Monitoring and alerting should be established early

8. What’s Next

This blog explained what is possible.
The next blogs series will be focused on how to implement.

entry.title: Re: Behind the Curtains - what's new about Maintenance Certificates
entry.content:
Dear Michael,

first of all, this new procedure is not a new method to renew or distribute the maintenance certificates / licenses. It is rather a replacement of this mechanism. When the new online check functionality is configured in your systems, you do not need the maintenance license in transaction SLICENSE anymore, hence it does not need to be renewed anymore. You can even delete the license for SW product Maintenance_<DB> from SLICENSE then.

As written above, you need at least Version 0091 of the SPAM/SAINT tool installed in your SAP system. And the SAP Host Agent must be on at least on version 67. When this is given, you can configure the federation functionality in your SAP Host Agent landscape. This means, you elect one SAP Host Agent as federation agent, which receives the requests of the other agents in your landscape. How this federation concept works and how it must be configured is explained in the SAP Host Agent documentation in SAP Help portal (see the link in the blog article). Note, that the federation concept is more general and the new online check of the maintenance entitlement is only one use case. In order to enable the online check, you must maintain logon information for the SAP Support Portal in the federation agent. And you must also allow the https communication from this host to apps.support.sap.com in your firewall. That's it, there is no configuration in the SPAM/SAINT tool needed.

You can check the function of the new online maintenance entitlement check in the system with report RSSPAM_TEST_ONLINE_MAINT_CHECK. If the check itself is not working it shows you the error message from the failing step; if it works it shows you whether there is a valid maintenance entitlement for your system or not.

The communication between the different parts happens via https. SPAM/SAINT is triggering a https request to the local SAP Host Agent of the SAP system, this forwards the request via the federation mechanism to the central federation agent and this contacts finally a service on apps.support.sap.com, which is checking the maintenance entitlement of the system. The result is going back this path, the SPAM/SAINT tool is getting the result and can react accordingly.

The EWA is already able to transfer its data independent from the Solution Manager to the SAP Support Portal. So, as far as I know, there are no plans to change this.

Best regards,
  Dirk

entry.title: Transport request/save locally popup not shown anymore in F2814 Manage KPI
entry.content:
I'm using S/4HANA 2023 FPS 01 ON-PREMISE (I think it's different in PUBLIC cloud, transport based on ATO).

When I changed a given standard KPI for the first time (F2814 Manage KPI), there was a popup with two options, "Save as a Local Object", or choose a customizing transport request:

I have chosen to save locally.

Now, I want to save it to a transport request, but if I change again, or anybody else change it, it saves, but the popup doesn't appear anymore.

How to save to a transport request?

I did another test, with another KPI, if I save it first to a transport request, then I delete manually the assignment to the transport request via SE10 (two lines with SSB1 for KPI, and SSB9 for an assigned report), the next time I save it, the popup is not shown and the KPI is not added to the original transport request.

So again, it's the same question as the first one, how to save to another transport request?

Thanks.

Sandra

entry.title: Re: Transport request/save locally popup not shown anymore in F2814 Manage KPI
entry.content:
When you modify a standard KPI for the very first time, SAP creates a customer extension record (in /SSB/EVALS, with ID = unique number based on the current date and time, and REF_ID = /SSB/EVAL_S - ID of the standard edited KPI), and asks if you want to save locally or in a customizing TR (transport request). Note the two different table names:

  • /SSB/EVAL_S: standard KPIs
  • /SSB/EVALS: customer extension records of standard KPIs (REF_ID contains the ID of the standard KPI in the table /SSB/EVAL_S) and brand new customer KPIs (REF_ID empty).

NB: after the modification of a standard KPI, one can name it a customer-edited KPI.

If you modify the standard KPI again, in fact you modify the customer extension, it no longer asks to save locally or in a TR.

What the standard does (because /SSB/EVALS-IS_EXTN_REVERTED is always different from '1'):

  • If the customer-edited KPI is not in a TR
    • The first time (the customer extension is created), the popup is displayed, asking to save locally or in a TR.
    • The next times (modification of the existing customer extension), the popup is not displayed.
  • If the customer-edited KPI is in a TR. the popup is not displayed.

SOLUTION - What the standard can't do, but there's a hidden logic: there is one special column IS_EXTN_REVERTED in the table /SSB/EVALS. Its manual modification is not supported but if you change it to '1' (AT YOUR OWN RISK), you'll get the popup:

  • If the customer-edited KPI is already in a TR, the popup is displayed without the "save locally" option, it asks for confirmation of the TR (but you can choose another one; this should be avoided because two TRs would contain the same KPI).
  • If the customer-edited KPI is not in a TR, the popup is displayed, asking to save locally or to a TR.

For information, my SQL fix (ID to be adjusted):

UPDATE "/SSB/EVALS"
SET IS_EXTN_REVERTED = '1'
WHERE ID = 'E.202601151554394197120'

More technical details (optional)

The Fiori App F2814 corresponds to the SAPUI5 application ANALYTICSDTS1, it calls the OData service SMART_BUSINESS_DESIGNTIME of the namespace /SSB/, which reads the KPI data from the entity set EVALUATIONS linked to the CDS view /ssb/designtime_Evaluations.

This CDS view contains the property IsCustomerEdited which is used to display the popup or not:

  • 0 means not Customer Edited -> Popup
  • 1 means Customer Edited version is currently available -> No popup
  • 2 means customer has edited it previously but then reverted it to get original SAP values -> Popup. It defaults the transport request to the current one containing the KPI (object R3TR SSB1 the key is /SSB/EVALS-ID). Note that if there's one transport request linked, the flag "save local" is not displayed.

IsCustomerEdited is based on the column IS_EXTN_REVERTED of the table /SSB/EVALS, its exact definition of IsCustomerEdited is in the CDS view /SSB/EVALS_WITH_CUST_EXTENSION:

 

define view /ssb/evals_With_Cust_Extension
as select from /ssb/Union
...
association [0..*] to /ssb/evals as _CustomerEdit on  $projection.id        = _CustomerEdit.ref_id
                                                  and $projection.namespace = 'S'
...
case when _CustomerEdit.ref_id is null
  then 0 // 0 means not Customer Edited
  when _CustomerEdit.ref_id is not null and _CustomerEdit.is_extn_reverted <> '1'
  then 1 // 1 means Customer Edited version is currently available.
  else 2 // 2 means customer has edited it previously but then reverted it to get original SAP values. 
end             as isCustomerEdited,

 

There are two entity sets/two methods of interest in the OData V2 service SMART_BUSINESS_DESIGNTIME of the namespace /SSB/ (SEGW / class /SSB/CL_SB_DESIGNTIME_DPC_EXT):

  • TR_CHECKS_GET_ENTITY (entity type TR_CHECK) contains the logic before the popup to determine SaveAsLocal ('0': no, '1': yes),  IsCustRequestId (is the customizing transport request to be provided? '0': No, '1': Yes) and CustRequestId (current customizing transport request assigned to the customer-edited KPI)
  • EVALUATIONS_UPDATE_ENTITY (entity type EVALUATION) contains the logic to update the KPI in the database after the popup, with some code about IS_EXTN_REVERTED of table /SSB/EVALS (it's reset to '0').

What the SAPUI5 application ANALYTICSDTS1 does when the user clicks the button "Save and activate" (NB: the entity sets below come from the OData service SMART_BUSINESS_DESIGNTIME):

  • It calls the function activate of KPICreateEditPage.controller.js, which calls the function _activate:
    • It calls the function checkTransportable of TransportManager.js
      • It calls the function fetchTransportParameters of CommonActions.js to set the property iTypeOfSAPDeliveredKPIEdit = IsCustomerEdited of the entity set EVALUATIONS (see above)
      • It calls the function callTransportChecks
        • It calls the function checkAndValidateTransport
          • It reads the entity set TR_CHECKS of the KPI to get local and transport information
  • It calls the function checkAndOpenDialog of TransportManager.js:
    • If a customizing request is required (IsCustRequestId = '1') or the KPI customer extension has been reverted (iTypeOfSAPDeliveredKPIEdit = 2)
      • It calls the function getTransportModelForDialog
        • It fetches the possible transport requests via the entity set TR_REQUESTS (functions getTransportModelForDialog and _fetchAndValidateTransportRequests)
        • It calls the function decideDialogFieldVisisbility which sets the variable SaveAsLocalVisible to define if the option "Save as a Local Object" is shown or not.
        • It calls the function OpenTransportDialog of TransportDialogManager.js, which displays the popup.

entry.title: Generation of customer-specific HU numbers as a contract manufacturer
entry.content:
Hello,

our customer is a manufacturer of its own products, but also a contract manufacturer for other companies. HU numbers and SSCC labels are used for pallets throughout the entire warehouse process.

A number range has been set up for the HU numbers, and this is fine for our client's own products.

However, certain customers for whom our client acts as a contract manufacturer have specific requirements for both the pallet labels and the HU numbers. These must be structured as follows:

Digit 1 = 3
Positions 2-8 = ILN
Positions 9-12 = Manufacturer number = 0008
Positions 13-17 = Freely selectable sequential number
Position 18 = Check digit according to GS1

Another customer for whom our customer acts as a contract manufacturer has similar requirements.

We do not yet have an approach for implementing the requirements in the public cloud and are therefore hoping for a solution or tips.

entry.title: Lessons Learned from a Key User Extensibility Hackathon in S/4HANA
entry.content:
Today, we ran an internal hackathon focused on Key User Extensibility in S/4HANA, with the explicit goal of evaluating it from a developer and clean-core perspective. We wanted to understand what it realistically enables, where it replaces classic approaches, and where it clearly does not.

The short version: we enjoyed the exercise, we learned a lot, and we ended up with working extensions in standard Fiori apps. But we also ran into several limitations that developers should be aware of before committing to this approach.

Scope and constraints (by design)

We deliberately constrained ourselves to:

  • Custom Fields (no table appends)

  • Custom Logic (no classic BAdIs, no user exits)

  • Standard Fiori apps

  • No direct modifications or enhancements in SAP namespaces

The goal was not to “make it work at all costs”, but to see how far you can get if you actually work with Key User Extensions

What worked well

Custom fields in standard apps

Once the right configuration was found, the core extensibility flow worked as advertised:

  • Custom fields could be created via Custom Fields

  • Enabled for usage in standard Fiori apps

  • Placed in the UI using Adapt UI

  • Displayed and updated correctly at runtime

From a technical standpoint, this is impressive. You can add customer-specific attributes to standard business objects without touching tables, includes, or generated structures—and the fields behave consistently in the UI and persistence layer.

Validation logic via Custom Logic

We successfully implemented validation rules using Custom Logic enhancement options:

  • Logic triggered during save

  • Errors surfaced directly in the Fiori UI

  • No need for explicit UI handling

For rules like “if flag X is set, field Y must be filled”, this works well and maps cleanly to governance-type requirements.

Where things became challenging (from a developer’s point of view)

Custom Logic is validation-centric

One of the first realizations was that Custom Logic is strongly biased toward validations.

There are very limited options for:

  • determinations

  • defaulting

  • derived values

For developers coming from classic ABAP (user exits, BAdIs, BEFORE_SAVE, etc.), this requires a mindset shift. Custom Logic is not meant to model business flows or calculation logic — it’s meant to protect data consistency, not drive behavior.

If you expect to replace classic determination logic with Custom Logic, you will likely be disappointed.

Tooling: neither developer-grade nor key-user-friendly

The web-based ABAP editor used for Custom Logic was one of the most discussed pain points.

From a developer perspective:

  • No ADT / Eclipse tooling

  • No refactoring support

  • Limited navigation

  • Limited debugging capabilities

At the same time, the logic itself is:

  • ABAP-based

  • strongly typed

  • requires technical understanding of structures and parameters

This puts Custom Logic in an awkward middle ground:

  • Too limited and uncomfortable for professional developers

  • Too technical for actual business key users

We would have strongly preferred the option to edit Custom Logic in ADT or SE80, while still deploying and governing it via the Key User Extensibility framework.

Only one implementation per enhancement option

Another structural limitation we encountered:

  • You can only create one implementation per enhancement option

This means:

  • No separation of concerns

  • No modularization of rules

  • No parallel ownership by different teams

All logic for a given hook ends up in a single implementation class. This works for demos and small scenarios, but it does not scale well in real systems where multiple rules evolve over time.

Publishing is serial and slow

From a team workflow perspective:

  • Only one person at a time can publish custom fields

  • Publishing can take a noticeable amount of time

  • Parallel development requires coordination

This is manageable, but it directly impacts productivity in collaborative settings such as hackathons or larger development teams.

Business contexts vs. classic technical thinking

Probably the biggest mental shift for developers was moving from tables and structures to business contexts.

Key User Extensibility is built around:

  • business semantics

  • usage scenarios

  • UI-driven contexts

For developers used to reasoning in terms of MARA, MVKE, EKKO, etc., it is not immediately obvious:

  • which context a field belongs to

  • where it will be persisted

  • which apps will actually consume it

This often required trial and error and inspecting available contexts, rather than following a clear technical mapping.

The outcome

Despite these challenges, we achieved our objective:

  • Custom fields were created

  • Validation logic was implemented

  • Fields were visible and editable in standard Fiori apps

  • No SAP core modifications were made

In other words: Key User Extensibility does work, but very clearly within its intended boundaries.

Final thoughts (for developers and architects)

Our main takeaway is:

Key User Extensibility is not a developer replacement for classic enhancements — it is a controlled, governance-focused extensibility mechanism.

It works well when:

  • you need customer-specific fields

  • you need simple validations

  • you want upgrade-safe UI extensions

It becomes limiting when:

  • you need determination logic

  • you expect full ABAP tooling

  • multiple teams need to extend the same object independently

The hackathon was absolutely worth doing. It helped us align on what clean core means in practical, technical terms, not just as a principle.

For anyone considering Key User Extensibility: try it hands-on, but go in with developer-realistic expectations.

entry.title: Request Current Market Data - Currency rates(Exchange rates)
entry.content:
SAP Market Data Management supports the following market data classes:

  • Currency rates (exchange rates)
  • Interest rates
  • Basis spreads
  • Credit spreads
  • General volatilities
  • FX swap rates
  • Security prices

This article covers: How to configure and request the Currency Exchange Rates Datafeed.

Datafeed incorporates current and historic market data into your financial transactions by means of the different SAP Market Rates Management services.

  • Define the data sources that can be accessed from the system in the configuration activity 'Define Data Sources for Datafeed'.
  • Subscribe to one of the following Market Rates Management service packages:
    a.) SAP Market Rates Management - Refinitiv data option: This is a paid service that is built for productive usage. It provides market data from Refinitiv, data provider.
    b.) SAP Market Rates Management - Bring Your Own Rates data option: This service can be used to import your own data that you have procured or licensed directly with data providers. Market rates are uploaded and downloaded using the SAP Market Rates Management service upload and download APIs.
  • Set up a communication arrangement for the SAP Treasury Market Rate Integration (SAP_COM_0203).
  • Translation tables must be defined before running any task to request market data and need to be set up only once for each type of market data. Assign Currency Notations – Datafeed app lets you define how currency exchange rates are imported from your datafeed provider and allows you to manually maintain translation tables between the datafeed and your master data.
  • To test your datafeed setup, run the apps Request Current Market Data and Request Historical Market Data.
  • Market data requests can be automated using the scheduling options available in the Request Current Market Data job template within the Schedule Treasury Back Office Jobs app.

Example

We take an example of the Bring Your Own Rates data option(BYOR).

  • Upload market rates from any source to the SAP Market Rates Management, Bring Your Own Rates data option APIs.

The instrument class and data provider are specified, such as instrument class 01 for currencies and data provider Y001 for SAP Business Technology Platform–based market data.
  • Enter translation tables manually in the Assign Currency Notations – Datafeed app to map datafeed values to your master data.

  • To set up the translation table for the Refinitiv data option, refer Reuters Instrument Codes (RICs)
  • Run Request Current Market Data.
  • Verify the result for market data request
References:
  1. Setup instructions for the 1S4 scope item.
  2. Market Data Management
  3. Request Market Data
  4. Datafeed
  5. SAP Market Rates Management, Refinitiv data option.
  6. SAP Market Rates Management, Bring Your Own Rates data option
